title: Baby, Let's Play House Elvis Presley and the Women Who Loved Him
description:

Just in time for Elvis PresleyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s would-be 75th birthday comes a new book by Elvis expert, journalist, and Country Music Association Media Achievement Award winner Alanna Nash. Called "by far the best study of Presley I have ever read. . . Impressively researched writtenÃ¢â‚¬â€and felt" by New York Times bestselling author Philip Norman (author of John Lennon and Shout!) and Ã¢â‚¬Å“the most entertaining Elvis book everÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ by New York Times bestselling author Jimmy McDonough (Shakey: Neil Young's Biography), Baby, LetÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Play House is the first-ever Elvis book to focus solely on his complex relationships with women, including celebrities such as Ann-Margret, Linda Thompson, Mary Ann Mobley, Cher, Raquel Welch, Barbara Eden, and Cybill Shepherd. Featuring dozens of exclusive interviews and scores of never-before-seen photos, Baby, LetÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Play House is a must-have collectorÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s item for fans of The King everywhere.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“An exhaustive and penetrating work that functions as an intimate personal profile, a family study and a psychosexual investigation of one of the 20th centuryÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s true cultural icons.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ (Memphis Commercial Appeal)

Ã¢â‚¬Å“A major new contribution to Presley lore...[Alanna NashÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s] focus on PresleyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationships with women takes us on a long and often fascinating journey...ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a welcome and well-crafted addition to our understanding of his strange, triumphant and tragic life.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ (The Globe and Mail)

Those who turned him down include Cher and Karen Carpenter. And of course, thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s plenty on the No. 1 woman in his life - Mom Gladys Presley.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ (New York Post)

I was delighted to see my stepmother, June Carter, make an appearance, as she always became uncharacteristically silent when ElvisÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ name came up in conversation. Raquel Welch! Barbara Eden! Tura Satana! This is very funny book.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ (Jimmy McDonough, New York Times bestselling author of Shakey: Neil Young's Biography)

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Deliciously gossipy but never mean, revealingly intimate but never leering, Baby, LetÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Play House is a masterwork of psycho-sexual history neatly disguised as celebrity journalism.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ (David Hajdu, author of Positively 4th Street, music critic for The New Republic, and professor at Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism David Hajdu, author of Positively 4th Street, music critic for The New Republic, and professor at Co)
From the Back Cover

Nearly thirty-three years after his death, Elvis Presley's extraordinary physical appeal, timeless music, and sexual charisma continue to captivate, titillate, and excite. Though hundreds of books have been written about the King, no book has solely explored his relationships with women and how they influenced his music and lifeÃ¢â‚¬â€until now.

Based largely on exclusive interviews with the many women who knew him in various rolesÃ¢â‚¬â€lover, sweetheart, friend, costar, and family memberÃ¢â‚¬â€Baby, Let's Play House explores Presley's love affairs with, among others, Ann-Margret, Linda Thompson, Sheila Ryan Caan, June Juanico, Joyce Bova, Barbara Leigh, Cybill Shepherd, and Priscilla Beaulieu, as well as his friendships with actresses Raquel Welch, Barbara Eden, Mary Ann Mobley, Yvonne Craig, and Celeste Yarnall.

The book also spotlights important early girlfriends and the women who dared to turn him down, including Cher, Petula Clark, and Karen Carpenter, as well as two womenÃ¢â‚¬â€Kay Wheeler and Tura SatanaÃ¢â‚¬â€who taught him dance moves he used onstage.

Baby, Let's Play House, named after the 1955 song that was his first to hit the national charts and his mother's favorite Elvis recording, presents Elvis in a new lightÃ¢â‚¬â€as a charming but wounded Lothario who bedded scores of women but seemed unable to maintain a lasting romantic relationship. While fully exploring the most famous romantic idol of the twentieth century, award-winning veteran music journalist Alanna Nash pulls back the covers on what Elvis really wanted in a womanÃ¢â‚¬â€and was tragically never able to find
